Summary functions like mean(), median(), min(), max(), etc. dt[, .(x = sum(b)), = ] - summarise rows within groups. dt[, c := 1+2] - compute column based expression. dt[==1, c := 1+2] - compute column based expression subset rows. dt[, `:=`(c=1, d=2)] - compute multiple columns based separate expressions. dt[, c := NULL] - delete column. dt_b[dt_a, = .(b = y)] - join data.tables rows equal values, similar left_join(dt_a, dt_b, = c("y" = "b")). dt_b[dt_a, = .(b = y, c > z)] - join data.tables rows equal unequal values. dcast(dt, id ~ y, value.var = c("", "b")) - Reshape data.table long wide format. dt data.table. id ~ y Formula LHS: ID columns containing IDs multiple entries. RHS columns values spread column headers. value.var Columns containing values fill cells. melt(dt, id.vars, measure.vars, variable.name, value.name) - Reshape data.table wide long format. dt data.table. id.vars ID columns IDs multiple entries. measure.vars Columns containng values fill cells (often pattern form). variable.name, value.name Names new columns variables values derived old headers.

code: height <- data.frame(   gender = c("Male", "Female", "Male", "Female", "Male", "Female"),   height = c(180, 165, 175, 160, 185, 170) ) # dplyr max_height_df <- height %>%   group_by(gender) %>%   dplyr::summarise(max_height = max(height))  # first transform data to data.table class data.table::setDT(height) max_height_dt <- height[,   .(max_height = max(height)),   by = gender ] # max_height_dt is now data.table format # and change it back to data.frame format if needed max_height_dt <- as.data.frame(max_height_dt)

previous_headings: Syntax of data.table and converting dplyr to data.table > Joining Large Datasets
title: Improve efficiency with `data.table`
text: Consider two large datasets df1 df2, containing information customers transactions. aim join datasets based common key, customer ID (customer_id). example comparison join operation using dplyr equivalent data.table: following demonstrate equivalent code various join types using dplyr data.table. join type ‚Äî left, right, full, inner, anti, semi ‚Äî serves different purposes merging datasets based common key. instance, full join retains rows datasets, inner join includes rows matching keys datasets. left right joins prioritize rows one dataset retaining unmatched rows . contrast, anti joins exclude rows matching keys, semi joins include rows least one match. providing equivalent code snippets join type dplyr data.table, aim illustrate flexibility efficiency packages handling various join scenarios, allowing users choose approach best fits specific requirements.
code: library(dplyr) library(data.table)  # Generate dummy data set.seed(123) n_rows <- 1e2  # Creating first dataset df1 <- data.frame(   customer_id = sample(1:(n_rows * 10), n_rows, replace = FALSE),   transaction_amount = runif(n_rows, min = 10, max = 100) )  # Creating second dataset df2 <- data.frame(   customer_id = sample(1:(n_rows * 10), n_rows, replace = FALSE),   customer_name = paste0("Customer_", sample(1:(n_rows * 10), n_rows, replace = FALSE)) )  # Joining with dplyr joined_df <- left_join(df1, df2, by = "customer_id") %>%   select(customer_id, transaction_amount, customer_name) %>%   arrange(customer_id)  # Converting to data.table dt1 <- data.table::as.data.table(df1) dt2 <- data.table::as.data.table(df2)  # Joining with data.table joined_dt <- dt2[dt1, on = "customer_id"] %>%   as.data.frame() %>%   select(customer_id, transaction_amount, customer_name) %>%   arrange(customer_id)  identical(joined_df, joined_dt) # TRUE # left join joined_df_left <- left_join(df1, df2, by = "customer_id") joined_dt_left1 <- dt2[dt1, on = "customer_id"] joined_dt_left2 <- merge(dt1, dt2, by = "customer_id", all.x = TRUE)  # right join joined_df_right <- right_join(df1, df2, by = "customer_id") joined_dt_right1 <- dt1[dt2, on = "customer_id"] joined_dt_rigth2 <-   merge(dt1, dt2, by = "customer_id", all.y = TRUE)  # inner join joined_df_inner <- inner_join(df1, df2, by = "customer_id") joined_dt_inner1 <- dt1[dt2, on = "customer_id", nomatch = NULL] joined_dt_inner2 <- merge(dt1,   dt2,   by = "customer_id",   all.x = FALSE,   all.y = FALSE )  # full join joined_df_full <- full_join(df1, df2, by = "customer_id") joined_dt_full2 <- merge(dt1, dt2, by = "customer_id", all = TRUE)  # anti join joined_df_anti <- anti_join(df1, df2, by = "customer_id") joined_dt_anti1 <- dt1[!dt2, on = "customer_id"]  # semi join joined_df_semi <- semi_join(df1, df2, by = "customer_id") joined_dt_semi1 <- dt1[dt2,   on = "customer_id",   nomatch = 0,   .(customer_id, transaction_amount) ]

code: library(dplyr) library(tidyr) library(data.table) # Example long-format data frame long_df <- data.frame(   ID = c(1, 1, 2, 2, 3),   key1 = c("A", "A", "B", "B", "C"),   key2 = c("W", "W", "X", "X", "Y"),   variable = c("value1", "value2", "value1", "value2", "value1"),   value = c(10, 100, 20, 200, 30) )  # Convert to wide format using dplyr wide_df <- long_df %>%   pivot_wider(     names_from = variable,     values_from = value   )  long_dt <- data.table::as.data.table(long_df) wide_dt <- dcast(long_dt,   ID + key1 + key2 ~ variable,   value.var = "value" )

code: library(dplyr) library(tidyr) library(data.table) # Example wide-format data frame wide_df <- data.frame(   ID = 1:5,   key1 = c("A", "B", "C", "D", "E"),   key2 = c("W", "X", "Y", "Z", "V"),   value1 = c(10, 20, 30, 40, 50),   value2 = c(100, 200, 300, 400, 500) )  # Convert to long format using dplyr long_df <- wide_df %>%   pivot_longer(     cols = starts_with("value"),     names_to = "variable",     values_to = "value"   )  wide_dt <- data.table::as.data.table(wide_df) long_dt <- melt(   wide_dt,   id.vars = c("ID", "key1", "key2"),   measure.vars = patterns("^value"),   variable.name = "variable",   value.name = "value" )

text: Conditional updates refer process modifying values dataset based specified conditions. words, involves updating certain values dataset meet specific criteria conditions. can particularly useful need apply changes dataset selectively, depending values certain variables combinations variables. instance, one might want update values column based whether meet certain thresholds, one might want apply different transformations different subsets data based criteria. title: Improve efficiency with `data.table`
text: dplyr data.table provide functionality performing conditional updates, allowing implement complex data transformations ease. operations often performed using functions like mutate() dplyr := data.table, along logical conditions specify updates occur. Suppose dataset containing information students‚Äô exam scores, want update scores based certain conditions. Let‚Äôs consider scenario want increase scores students scored certain threshold. dplyr example, use mutate() function update exam_score column based condition specified inside ifelse(). exam_score 70, increase 5; otherwise, keep unchanged. data.table example, use := operator update exam_score column directly within dataset. logical condition exam_score < 70 used specify rows updated, expression exam_score + 5 used define new values rows. approaches achieve result: updating exam scores students scored 70. However, differ syntax implementation, showcasing flexibility dplyr data.table performing conditional updates. Similarly, data.table::fcase() equivalent version dplyr::case_when().
code: library(dplyr) library(data.table) # Dummy dataset scores_df <- data.frame(   student_id = 1:10,   exam_score = c(75, 82, 65, 90, 55, 78, 70, 85, 60, 72) ) # Increase scores for students with scores below 70 updated_scores_df <- scores_df %>%   mutate(exam_score = ifelse(exam_score < 70, exam_score + 5, exam_score))  # Convert to data.table scores_dt <- as.data.table(scores_df) # Increase scores for students with scores below 70 scores_dt[exam_score < 70, exam_score := exam_score + 5] scores_dt[, exam_score := fifelse(exam_score < 70, exam_score + 5, exam_score)] scores_dt[, exam_score := fcase(exam_score < 70, exam_score + 5)]
